comment.narrative:
Baseline 1: Poor understanding in LPCs and strategic regions of biofouling management practices and limited national policies or regulations focused on preventing the transfer of IAS through biofouling
Baseline 2: LPCs have limited resources to train national stakeholders and authorities. Existence of global knowledge gaps and limited technical resources to assist in the implementation of sound biofouling management. No identified pool of expertise within strategic regions
Baseline 3: Limited awareness of biofouling issues, the impact of IAS and available solutions in LPCs and, more broadly, the international shipping community and other ocean industries
Baseline 4: LPCs with limited experience in implementing biofouling management measures
Baseline 5: Limited public-private cooperation to identify needs and develop technological solutions to better manage biofouling
Limited awareness of business opportunities related to biofouling management solutions and technologies within the investment community
Baseline 6: Biofouling management information and knowledge is globally disjunct and difficult to access, with limited forums for discussion of biofouling issues at the global level with the inclusion of developing countries
Baseline 7: No existing project staff or structure in place
M&E plan included in Project document

Target 1: National Task Forces in place in 10 out of 12 LPCs
National biofouling management strategies and action plans developed in 6 out of 12 LPCs
Target 2: At least 3 guidance documents and reports developed and published to assist in the technical aspects of biofouling management in all sectors. At least 2 training packages developed and used for training at least 100 (50 male; 50 female) participants
Target 3: Project website in place and at least 25 communication and awareness-raising materials developed in different formats (e.g. printed, audiovisual, etc.) and distributed effectively to all stakeholders through traditional and new media platforms
Target 4: LPCs identify demonstration projects to showcase strategic biofouling management strategies
Target 5: Industry task forces and funds set up, with contributions from at least 5 shipping and non-shipping private sector companies and producing work plans
At least 2 platforms set up to facilitate participation of industry in R&D discussions and to catalyse investment in biofouling management solutions and technologies
Target 6: Knowledge hub created and one R&D Forum organised, facilitating the participation of voices from developing countries and facilitating North-South technology transfer
Target 7: All project management structures in place by end of 1st year and M&E plan fully implemented for first two years of project
Mid-term evaluation

Result 1: National workshops organized in 10 out of 12 Lead Partnering Countries (LPCs) to raise awareness of the issue and for preliminary discussion on institutional arrangements and key aspects at the national level. This has resulted in the setup of national task forces in 10 out of 12 LPCs (Brazil, Fiji, Indonesia, Jordan, Madagascar, Mauritius, Mexico, Philippines, Sri Lanka and Tonga). The two remaining LPCs (Peru and Ecuador) are set to create their NTFs in July 2020 (outside this reporting period).
1 Regional workshop organized in the Pacific region with the collaboration of SPREP to present the project and encourage the Regional Task Force on invasive aquatic species to include the biofouling issue in the regional agenda and to lead the development of a regional strategy.
1 Regional workshop organized in the Mediterranean region with the collaboration of REMPEC to present the issue of biofouling and encourage inclusion of the issue in the regional agenda.
2 national workshops organized in Nigeria and Ukraine to present the issue of biofouling to key national stakeholders.
Result 2: 2 guidance documents are currently in development (Guidance on rapid status assessments and Guidance on economic assessments). Selection of experts for the development of a third guidance document (Guidance for national strategies) is underway.
1 training package in development (general training course on biofouling management and invasive aquatic species).
2 Best practice documents in development by WOC and IOC-UNESCO.
GESAMP working group 44 on biofouling management approved. Chair selected and recruitment of other members is ongoing.
10 workshops organized in LPCs with 360 participants (125 female; 235 male).
Result 3: 21 communication and awareness raising materials developed: 17 news items, 2 photo stories, 1 newsletter, 1 video animation.
Project website in place (Average sessions per month: 1,115. Average page views per month: 2,890).
Social media accounts in place (Twitter, Instagram, LinkedIn, Flickr).
Result 4: Members of National Task Forces in 10 out of 12 LPCs have stated preliminary preference for theme of demonstration projects in their country. However, Covid 19 lockdown and movement/travel restrictions have put a halt to the implementation of any physical demonstration project in all 12 LPCs.
Result 5: Global Industry Alliance (GIA) Partnership established with four founding industry partners (ECOsubsea, HullWiper, Sonihull and CleanSubSea). A GIA Trust Fund has been established, with IMO being the fiduciary of the Fund. The starting capital of the Fund is US$75,000, contributed by the GIA founding partners.
1 Industry Panel organized at 1st R&D Forum and chaired by WOC to discuss major issues faced by the private sector with regard to the implementation of biofouling management solutions.
1 session on biofouling at Sustainable Ocean Summit organized by WOC (November 2019) to increase awareness on the environmental issue and encourage active participation of the industry and the private sector.
Result 6: Knowledge hub created, with six functioning modules. Average sessions per month: 625
1 International R&D conference organized in Melbourne, Australia, (2019) with 161 participants.
8 webinars organized showcasing key aspects and research related to biofouling management and invasive aquatic species.
Participation in 1 regional conference on Biofouling, Benthic Ecology and Marine Biotechnology (Brazil, 2019).
Result 7: Fully functional four-member Programme Coordination Unit at IMO.
UN2UN Agreement signed and financial arrangements in place with IOC-UNESCO. Recruitment of 1 project support staff at IOC-UNESCO
Implementation agreement and financial arrangements between IOC-UNESCO and World Ocean Council in place.
5 agreements with Regional Coordination Organizations (RCO) established (CPPS, PEMSEA, PERSGA, SACEP and SPREP). For the West Indian Ocean, the project will work with IMO’s Regional Coordinator in Kenya. National focal points and national project coordinators appointed in 12 out of 12 LPCs.
Strategic Partnerships established with industry associations, NGOs, research institutions, developed countries, classification societies and women in maritime associations.
Project M&E and coordination structure in place, including:
1st Global Project Task Force (GPTF) meeting (Inception workshop - March 2019), with attendance of all LPCs, RCOs, implementing partners, and strategic partners.
The 1st Executive Committee meeting took place in April 2020, with special focus on the impact of COVID-19 and assess alternative ways to implement activities where physical presence or travel was required and to minimise delays in project implementation.
1 Risk assessment meeting with LPCs and RCOs to assess impact and mitigation of COVID-19.
5 Quarterly and 1 Annual Project Reports submitted to UNDP.
